title: 109_hr6116
content: The Act titled "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" enhances the Border Patrol agent force. The "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to submit a plan within six months to improve recruitment and retention of Border Patrol agents. The plan must include strategies for recruitment and retention of well-qualified agents. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a plan to improve recruitment and retention of Border Patrol agents, including assessing current pay levels, flexibility in transferring agents, and strategies for retaining well-qualified agents. SEC. 3. Recruitment and retention bonuses for Border Patrol agents enhancement. Sec. 9702 of Chapter 97 of title 5, United States Code, allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to pay recruitment bonuses to individuals to recruit Border Patrol agents, not exceeding 25% of the annual rate of basic pay. The bonus is paid as a lump-sum and is not part of basic pay. Payment of a bonus under this section is contingent upon entering into a written service agreement with the United States Border Patrol, specifying the service period and conditions for termination. The bonus cannot be paid to recruit individuals for certain high-level positions. The authority to pay bonuses under this section applies to noncareer appointees or positions excepted from competitive service due to their policy-related nature. The termination of bonus authority occurs five years after enactment. Additionally, the Secretary of Homeland Security can provide retention bonuses to Border Patrol agents under specific conditions outlined in a service agreement. The bonus agreement for Border Patrol agents includes the required service period and conditions for termination. The bonus amount is determined by the Secretary and cannot exceed 25% of the annual pay. The bonus is paid as a lump sum and cannot be part of basic pay. The bonus cannot be based on a period already used for a recruitment bonus. The authority to grant bonuses under this subsection expires five years after enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security may appoint annuitants to Border Patrol positions without certain provisions applying to them. The authority to appoint annuitants to Border Patrol positions expires five years after enactment, with limitations on appointments and exclusions for annuitants after a certain period. The term 'annuitant' is defined in section 8331 or 8401. A conforming amendment is made to the table of contents for chapter 97 of title 5, United States Code. Border Patrol agent enhancement.
